content:
I've just updated the last test ("Not starting in .") to be more similar to the last validator ("LePoulpeVolant Validator"):

-a,-L 4
23

./Directory1/File2

./Directory1/File4

./File6
./.File7

./Directory2/DirectoryA/DirectoryIII/File9
./Directory2/DirectoryA/DirectoryIII/.File10
./.Directory3/File11
./.Directory3/File13
./.Directory3/.File12

./Directory4/Directory5/Directory6
-a,-L 4
23
./Directory1/File1
./Directory1/File2
./Directory2/File3
./Directory1/File4
./Directory2/DirectoryA/File5
./File6
./.File7

./Directory2/DirectoryA/Directory6/.File10

./.Directory3/.File12

./Directory4/Directory5/Directory6/Directory9/Directory10/Directory11/Directory12/Filee
./Directory4/Directory5/Directory6/Directory9/Directory10/Directory11/Filef
./Directory4/Directory5/Directory6/Directory7/File18
./Directory4/Directory5/Directory6/Directory7/.File17
./Directory4/Directory5/Directory6/Directory7/.File16
./Directory4/Directory5/Directory6/Directory7/File19

No change in the output.

There was a reported problem with testcase 9 so I edited this part of the description:

The tree needs to be sorted in ascending alphabetical order , letters in lowercase having priority on uppercases and without considering the leading and first character ‘.’ (dot) from hidden files or directories names.

for this:

The tree needs to be sorted in ascending, alphabetical, case insensitive order and without considering the leading and first character ‘.’ (dot) from hidden files or directories names.
Added LePoulpeVolant's test pair from https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-advanced-tree/2223/56?u=jbm

FYI... I have modified Big Test 1 so that it has duplicated directory names at a given level. Apparently this has tripped up several people already, and none of the tests had this. It was only in validators.

I've implemented it.

I'm raising the alarm on the combination of the "Hidden Files with -a Validator" case with the sort ordering specification. It's the very only case in the whole set that doesn't pass using simplified ordering "sort on ASCII codes, bit 5 flipped, ignoring dots".
I'd suggest:
- swapping test and validator on this one (or provide an actual more in-depth sort ordering test), and
- rewriting the sort ordering sentence

Probable bug: "Wrong File" test/validator. This so much seems like it should be "Wrong Flag" I'll correct it myself, but do fix back if I'm the one who got it wrong.

Personal comments:
I like the idea. I like part of the complexity. I like the fact there are a LOT of test cases that make TD implementation feasible. I like the fact this problem has improved a lot since it was first submitted, it makes it fell like moderation can be useful.
I dislike the error handling. Not that I'm against having *some* of it, but it tends to either overconstrain the implementation to the problem setter's design, or summon warts over mine, so ugh. In our case, why report dir/file counts if there was an error? (rhetorical question: the answer isn't important, the fact the problem solver has to wonder is)

Okay. I have solved this. Here are my comments.

PLUS:

 - There's more to this than I expected. Lots of little details to get right.
 - There's a LOT of tests that do a pretty good job of walking the user through the requirements.

MINUS:

 - I don't think that it states anywhere that hidden files are sorted without the leading '.' character. My initial implementation sorted them high in the list because '.' comes before all letters.

 - Many of the validators contain a structure with "gaps" in the vertical ancestor lines. A good example is "Hidden Files w/o -a Validator". Only two of the (non-validator) tests contain a structure like this: "Directory Flag Test" and "Big Test". The first has only a single line with a single missing vertical, so it's not immediately obvious what's expected from that test. The "Big Test" is complex enough that it might not be obvious where the failure is in that test.

 - I don't think any of the tests contain a non-printed hidden directory. If someone implements their logic poorly, then only "Hidden Files w/o -a Validator" will fail.

 - I don't think any of the tests contains a file with a '.' in the middle of it (i.e. Final_Rendering.js). It looks like these are only in validators. If someone implements their hidden file logic wrong, then they might have validators failing for non-obvious reasons.

 - The "-L -7" flag in the validator is pretty nasty. My original implementation thought this was valid. It's an integer! I can foresee a lot of people getting tripped up by this, and no way to debug.

 - It's a common theme here, but in general the validators are quite a bit more complex than the tests. For example, "Big Validator" is much bigger than "Big Test". More and more, I'm becoming wary of validators that are noticeably more complex than associated tests. It opens up the possibility of boundary condition failures that can't be easily debugged.

I like the puzzle, and very much want to approve it, but as-is, I still can't give it the nod. Please make some updates and reply to this message, and I will go ahead and approve it.

Thanks for the ASCII!

Additional comments:
- the commas to separate flags seem very out-of-character.
- the "there will be no tricky paths" comment is well-meant, but next to worthless. Would you be able to actually specify what will/won't be in the test cases?

Why "0 directories"?
Why not "0 directory"?

Characters switched into UTF8/Unicode ASCII chars
All validators edited and ready to go !

I haven't solved it yet, but I made some modifications to the problem statement to correct spelling and grammar. I agree that the "extended" characters should be changed to something else. It's a good puzzle, but I won't be approving it until this change is made..

Haven't checked much beyond this, but "ASCII-extended" doesn't really mean anything. More specifically, the CG problems' I/O tends to use Unicode/UTF8, and it's a Massive Pain to use in a few languages, notably Lua.

Please stick to actual ASCII.

You don't explain correctly how hidden files and dirs work. In windows it doesn't work like in Linux/Mac.
I think you just need the validators (and maybe, name test/validators for what are you testing)

Will work on validators later, hope you'll enjoy it !

If something is too much approximate, don't hesitate to tell me in comments here

Added a precision on errors handling; 
- "Incorrect flags must be skipped."

Mmh, you're right ! I'm currently working on new validators.

Thanks for this reply =)

Argh.. Do I really need to change this, since I give characters in the statement ?
Anyways, i think i will have no problems to switch into ASCII if it's really needed :)

Thanks for your feedback and your statement modifications :)

Well, i spoke to JBM yesterday about "extended" chars (he doesn't like to call them ASCII-extended lol), and yeah, i'll replace them into standard chars "|,`,-" (like the original tree command with --charset="ascii") when i'll be done with new validators.

Again, thanks a lot for your feedback :D

When creating the puzzle, I wanted to create the same or at least the same behaviour as the original UNIX tree, and the original tree doesn't handle the singular name when there is no directory neither file..

Nope, it's not a mistake from me that i didn't handle the "0" :p

- I don't get what you mean by "out-of-character", can you be more precise ?
- Mmh ok, will do it (even it's a lil complex to explain exactly)

Wow, if I could upvote this multiple times, i would do it

More seriously, I will work on it now, since there are much things to fix !
Thanks a loooot about that comment, i really prefer critics about mistakes like this, even if i need to be perfect since the first post lol

Did a few typography and clarity edits.

I'd suggest moving anything more hint than specification in your last paragraph to the Constraints section, to lighten the problem text.
I've revised the input and output of Example (Validator 1) to make the validator different from Test 1.

Duhh, first of all, yeah, that was totally a mistake about the "Wrong File" > "Wrong Flag" thing, I just saw the fix so thanks

I think that, yeah, i'll just swap test and validator for "Hidden Files with -a" (plus it's much more appropriate to be a test than a validator, due to the possible "bugs" you can have on it with a "bad" solution).

Yeah, i was wondering about the sort ordering earlier today, and i think it needs to be more detailled, so yeah, i'm gonna edit that now.

Well, I personally like to have to do error handling in my programs (well, i learnt to have to do it all the time), and, maybe i'm wrong, but i think more puzzles needs to have more of that.

Also, to answer your last question why "report dir/file counts if there was an error?", well, because the original Tree does. Like i said above in a comment, i originally created this puzzle to be the closest possible with the same behaviour as the UNIX tree (of course, with less flags).

So yeah, I don't really know which is best for exemple between no error handling at all, or this current one.. but i'll stay on that i guess

(I'm new at CG puzzle and I know I'm not perfect (nobody is) but I think i need some time to be really OK with all this stuff :p)

- Edited in the statement about the sorting for hidden files/directories
- Test case added for gap for a possible last folder => Gap End of Tree Handling
- Test case added for hidden directories without the -a flag => Hidden Directories w/o -a
- Test case added for dots in a filename (except the first character) => Dots in Filenames
- Edited in the statement about the -L flag that must be positive

Well, since i added these test cases, i think that the big validator is OK since everything can be debugged :)

Thanks again for the comment, i prefer it to be perfect and without issues before being approved :D

Oh so close! Everything looks good except the "Dots in Filenames Test". It contains a hidden and a non-hidden version of Directory2. My code groups the files in these two directories separately. The answer groups the two together as if they are a single directory. If this is the intended behavior, then I think it should be documented as such, though I think that would be pretty strange since they are obviously separate directories in the filesystem.

If they are not grouped together, then it is undefined which one is sorted before the other. :-)
*sigh* I want to kill myself  sometimes.. Fixed + edited in the statement that it can't be possible (but maybe in a future harder version :p)
Awesome! Thanks for your hard work and dedication to excellence. I am satisfied, and have voted to approve this puzzle.
Thanks :D
It's out of character because UNIX command-line arguments are not comma-separated.

Well yeah, but a "possible" tricky list of flags with commas could be for exemple '-aLdL 3 2' and will be displaying hidden dirs/files, only directories and limiting the depth displaying to "2" and not 3.

To be honest, I want to create other versions for the tree: a simplified version, and an "expert" version, so i think i'll do it in an harder version :)

EDIT: Updated the "There will be no tricky paths" comment to be more clearer
I personally wouldn't believe much in making command line parsing the core of the problem. There are libraries for that anyway, and they're readily available on the CG platform.
If i'm doing a harder version, there will be not only a harder flag parsing anyways ^^

Added two test cases :
- Check in directory in directory
- Big case one
Fixed my solution, was buggy somewhere :(

EDIT: My tree printing needs to be fixed, it's totally messing up somewhere, gonna re-do it soon :|
